body: Ok than for release 8.x :-)

This will slow down the startup for all "normal" (WAR) applications :-/
Could you please create a quickstart to play with? I think we can improve further by `break`-ing once we exit `/META-INF/wicket/` directory. I.e. I think iterating over the jar entries will go over all entries in `/META-INF/wicket/` and then process other directories. So once it enters in `/META-INF/wicket/` we can raise a flag, later when it exits then we should `break`.

Here you go: https://github.com/robertbraeutigam/wicket-uberjar-sandbox

As far as I know, there is no "exiting" and "entering" directories in Jar files, since it is composed of 'entries' in no particular order. I don't think we can get around that, unless we can get rid of scanning the classpath altogether somehow.

As for slowing down "normal" applications, I think the real solution would be not to do classpath scanning, but to use java.util.ServiceLoader or similar approach. The "shade" maven plugin for example can deal with merging these standard Service files at least, so that would solve this "uberjar" issue and would be even faster (and more standard-compliant) than the current solution.

> java.util.ServiceLoader or similar approach

Maybe for Wicket 8 ...
Unless there is a backward compatible way to do this now.

I remember both maven-shade-plugin and OSGi had problems with ServiceLoader. Maybe they are fixed in latest versions.
After discussion, it has been decided to keep it the way it is. Closing the PR.
@svenmeier I've reworked the patch.
That looks better.

Thanks for the contribution!
But since Wicket itself won't use it I think it should not be part of wicket-ajax-jquery.js. It could be part of Wicket-Select2 project, for example.

Let's see what other Wicket devs think about it.

The was a discussion at Wicket dev@ mailing list and we decided to deprecate the current way and use ServiceLoader from now on.
Please see https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/WICKET-5997 and http://markmail.org/message/o5jvwjmmezu4xebe for more details.
Please close this PR because we don't have permissions to do it!
Thank you for raising this issue!
I agree with Martin here: Why have a method in Wicket, when it's not used by Wicket?
@martin-g any other hints? :smiley:
Hope the implementation gets closer to the final state.

PathResourceStream is still missing.
Give it a go! It shouldn't be something complex. Once ready with its impl see whether it could be used by FileSystemResource.
That was the point I asked for help. I don't actualy want to break the API with that changes.

Don't worry. There is nothing to break. It won't be used anywhere else for now.
Use FileResourceStream as inspiration. They should look almost the same.
@martin-g Would you be so kind and review the PathResourceStream class?
No other comments from me.
Should I provide an additional FileSystemStreamReference (using path) - like org.apache.wicket.core.util.resource.locator.caching.FileResourceStreamReference?

Good catch!
Yes, we will need it.
Ok, FileSystemResourceStreamReference is implemented.
Done.

No further comments by me.
If no one objects then please merge it to master and 7.x.
Closed due to commits https://github.com/apache/wicket/commit/e0c2f1bbae576d26f2dc54996905e9acb63ccca0 and https://github.com/apache/wicket/commit/cdd9a6d56f05d37639f01b31091fb4bfd13ab926
Any other suggestions? I've not changed the IModel<?>, currently - because of the conflict between Serializable / and the IModel of Serializable. Any hint to solve that?

OK, I see.
Then make the other constructor accepting `Serializable` instead of `String`. As `Label` does :-)
What about my remark? For srcset I'd prefer to have a model of list instead of an array of models.

@martin-g I already changed it. :smiley: 
@svenmeier in the current image / source implementation we also use varargs for the srcset. I think we should provide a uniform API across image / source components to not confound users. But lets discuss that. Maybe we find a way to uniform it even with the model of list

Maybe we can add the following constructor to also support your requirements:
ExternalImage(String id,Model<Serializable> src,Model<List<Serializable>> srcSet)

I don't find it confusing:
- Image has IResource...
- ExternalImage has Serializable... _and_ IModel<List<? extends Serializable>>

IModel... looks strange to me, IMHO the need to have #convertToModel() shows how strange it is to have an array of models.

I agree with Sven that `IModel<List>` is better than varargs.
We had issues with varargs in StringResourceModel and we broke the API in 7.x to improve it.
I also think it would be harder for the application to provide the parameters as varargs, than as List.
Maybe we should deprecate the varargs signature in the other new components ? Or at least add new constructor with List and wait for some feedback in the coming months.

+1 too, not fan of `IModel...`.

Then I guess it would be possible to add a `ExternalImage(String id, IModel<List<Seriarizable>> srcSetModel)` ctor ;)

Another remark I did earlier about my concern on `src != null ? Model.of(src) : null`. It means that supplying a null value will result of a null model, leading to a search of a compound model in the component hierarchy, which is confusing IMHO.

Well ok then! :smile: Two tasks:
1. Change varargs to List.
2. Apply src directly to super()

May one more task:

3 . Add new constructors to Image / Source to support IModel<List<ResourceReference>> and set the varargs constructors to deprecated.

Hi, I first changed only ExternalImage / ExternalSource - if everything is finished with that I am going to commit the changes on Image / Source.

Hope the last commit is like you want it to be.

Only for comparison

Lists:

``` java
ExternalImage externalImage2 = new ExternalImage("externalImage2",
"http://wicket.apache.org/img/wicket-7-bg.jpg",
Arrays.<Serializable>asList(
"http://wicket.apache.org/img/wicket-7-bg-1.jpg",
"http://wicket.apache.org/img/wicket-7-bg-2.jpg"));
```

Varargs:

``` java
ExternalImage externalImage2 = new ExternalImage("externalImage2",
"http://wicket.apache.org/img/wicket-7-bg.jpg",
"http://wicket.apache.org/img/wicket-7-bg-1.jpg",
"http://wicket.apache.org/img/wicket-7-bg-2.jpg");
```

Thank you for the time you spend to review the code! :+1: Any other things to be changed? 

Anyway - you have convinced me about the list arg over the var arg - the additional code is rather small and the whole component is type safe, now.
I'm going to implement the second solution, but with a check if the srcModel is not null - what do you think?

I am not sure because:
- having a _non_-null _model_ is the responsibility of the user.
- handling null model _object_ is our responsibility because it happens at runtime

If I'm not wrong, Wicket usually let throw a NPE is thrown in case of null _model_...
Yep you are right! I changed it the way to only check the model object.
Anything else? Next step would be - squash, integrate and cherrypick onto 7.x branch
To me that's all fine, thank you very much Tobias! :)
Other things?
Well then I'm going to integrate it! :+1:

_Integrated_

The changes look good!
But isn't it better to use includes instead?
It is much easier to control what you want in then what you want out. For example when I add some third party library I'll have to investigate what CSS resources there are and exclude them.
It'd be much easier to list only the ones I'd like to process.
Okay - I will turn around that logic.

If I turn around that logic I will break the behavior, because you have to provide those settings and if users upgrading to the new wicket version and don't have set those css file names the functionality is broken.
The performance increased way better with the new regex. We should discuss changes in the jira ticket. I made a suggestion there.

Just to clarify, I am not simply converting spaces to tabs or vice-versa to my liking. I fix indentation when a code in one scope has different levels of indentation (or different nested scopes and same indentation) which makes it hard to read.

Something got broken, because it is not possible to ensure that Application is set before the LTW of AspectJ processes the weaving. Have to find a way for this.

Hi Martin,

I just added a lot of stuff I made yesterday. I split every measurement into a single class so that you can decide much better what you want to measure and what you don't want to.

In addition I added a guide how to define own metric aspects in the guide.

The last thing I've done is to move it to experimental and fixed the artifact id to be *wicket8 instead of *wicket7 - Is this project automatically released with wicket 8 core?

I also added a template so that you can see what to define if you want to have all stuff. Just open a resource in your ide called "wicket-metrics.template.xml" if you have added the maven dependency.
Integrated
@geof379 Please close this Pull Request.

Hi Martin,

thanks for reviewing. I am going to convert the replace to char only - are you able to test the metrics within your project? I did already and they were working for me.

I thought that a HttpSessionListener is the best choice for the session count - but if metadata-complete is set to true you have to configure the listener yourself.

The fallback from Application.get() > Application.get(String) > static members are completely configurable.

Integrated:

master: https://github.com/apache/wicket/commit/50b6cadc5d44a45c261f599501cac20b5c20c766
wicket-7.x: https://github.com/apache/wicket/commit/20c3b9982dffbb265bb176439414622169b1533a

@martin-g - One thing which has to be done so that the measurement of the session is working correctly is to clear the session storage from disc after restarting the server, because otherwise stored session leads to negative session counts, because they are restored and expire.

There is no good solution to handle this out of the box by the servlet API, because anywhere you persist the information about a session count it can be erased. (tmp folder, realPath(), etc.)

I made a hint into the guide. I also removed the jsessionid from the path of the request measurement.

wicket-core doesn't use CGLIB!
wicket-ioc does use CGLIB.
I'm afraid your PR is invalid.
seems the dynamic cglib import are comming from pax wicket.. SO I will fix it there, where it should be fixed!

Guys, question: why aspectj is required here? Wicket do allow instrument code through IClassResolver. Doing that through this class will allow do not load java agent and enable/disable this feature right at runtime.
